hints_html: Using the information from part a), the matrix of T can be described by using the eigenvectors and eigenvalues.
hints_latex:
Using the information from part
{a)},
the matrix of \emph{T} can be described by using the eigenvectors and
eigenvalues.
hints_raw: Using the information from part [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH221/April_2013/Question_07_(a)|a)]], the matrix of ''T'' can be described by using the eigenvectors and eigenvalues.
question: 7 (b)
sols_html:
’ What we know from part a)’

Using the eigenvectors \(\left[ \begin{array}{c} 4 \\ 3 \end{array} \right] , \left[ \begin{array}{c} -3 \\ 4 \end{array} \right]\), and the eigenvalues \(1,-1\), we know that \(A\left[ \begin{array}{c} 4 \\ 3 \end{array} \right] = \left[ \begin{array}{c} 4 \\ 3 \end{array} \right]\) and \(A\left[ \begin{array}{c} -3 \\ 4 \end{array} \right] = -\left[ \begin{array}{c} -3 \\ 4 \end{array} \right]\).

’ Finding the formula for the matrix \(A\)’

Then, we can write the information from above in matrix notation \(A \left[ \begin{array}{cc} 4 & -3 \\ 3 & 4 \end{array} \right] = \left[ \begin{array}{cc} 4 & -3 \\ 3 & 4 \end{array} \right]\left[ \begin{array}{cc} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 \end{array} \right].\)

We define the matrix \(B\), where the columns of \(B\) are the eigenvectors and write the equation as

\(AB = B\left[ \begin{array}{cc} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 \end{array} \right].\)

This leads us to \(A = B \left[ \begin{array}{cc}1 & 0 \\ 0 & -1\end{array} \right] B^{-1}\).

’ Calculating \(A\)’

First the inverse of B is given by the usual method for 2x2 matrices (where \(25 = \det(B)\)):

\(B^{-1} = \frac{1}{25} \left[ \begin{array}{cc} 4 & 3 \\ -3 & 4 \end{array} \right]\)

We can now compute A as claimed:

\(A = \left[ \begin{array}{cc} 4 & -3 \\ 3 & 4 \end{array} \right] \left[ \begin{array}{cc} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 \end{array} \right] \left( \frac{1}{25} \left[ \begin{array}{cc} 4 & 3 \\ -3 & 4 \end{array} \right]\right) = \frac{1}{25} \left[ \begin{array}{cc} 7 & 24 \\ 24 & -7 \end{array} \right]\).
sols_latex:
\emph{' What we know from part
{a)}}'

Using the eigenvectors
$\left[ \begin{array}{c} 4 \\ 3  \end{array} \right] , \left[ \begin{array}{c} -3 \\ 4  \end{array} \right]$,
and the eigenvalues $1,-1$, we know that
$A\left[ \begin{array}{c} 4 \\ 3  \end{array} \right]  = \left[ \begin{array}{c} 4 \\ 3 \end{array} \right]$
and
$A\left[ \begin{array}{c} -3 \\ 4 \end{array} \right] = -\left[ \begin{array}{c} -3 \\ 4 \end{array} \right]$.

\emph{' Finding the formula for the matrix $A$}'

Then, we can write the information from above in matrix notation
$A \left[ \begin{array}{cc} 4 & -3 \\ 3 & 4 \end{array} \right] = \left[ \begin{array}{cc} 4 & -3 \\ 3 & 4 \end{array} \right]\left[ \begin{array}{cc} 1 & 0  \\ 0 & -1 \end{array} \right].$

We define the matrix $B$, where the columns of $B$ are the eigenvectors
and write the equation as

$AB = B\left[ \begin{array}{cc} 1 & 0  \\ 0 & -1 \end{array} \right].$

This leads us to
$A = B \left[ \begin{array}{cc}1 & 0  \\ 0 & -1\end{array} \right] B^{-1}$.

\emph{' Calculating $A$}'

First the inverse of \emph{B} is given by the usual method for 2x2
matrices (where $25 = \det(B)$):

$B^{-1}  = \frac{1}{25} \left[ \begin{array}{cc}
4 & 3  \\ 
-3 & 4
\end{array} \right]$

We can now compute \emph{A} as claimed:

$A = \left[ \begin{array}{cc}
4 & -3  \\ 
3 & 4
\end{array} \right] \left[ \begin{array}{cc}
1 & 0  \\ 
0 & -1
\end{array} \right] \left( \frac{1}{25}  \left[ \begin{array}{cc}
4 & 3  \\ 
-3 & 4
\end{array} \right]\right)  = \frac{1}{25} \left[ \begin{array}{cc}
7 & 24  \\ 
24 & -7
\end{array} \right]$.
sols_raw:
''' What we know from part [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH221/April_2013/Question_07_(a)|a)]]'''

Using the eigenvectors <math> \left[ \begin{array}{c} 4 \\ 3  \end{array} \right] , \left[ \begin{array}{c} -3 \\ 4  \end{array} \right] </math>, and the eigenvalues <math>\ 1,-1</math>, we know that
<math> A\left[ \begin{array}{c} 4 \\ 3  \end{array} \right]  = \left[ \begin{array}{c} 4 \\ 3 \end{array} \right] </math>
and
<math> A\left[ \begin{array}{c} -3 \\ 4 \end{array} \right] = -\left[ \begin{array}{c} -3 \\ 4 \end{array} \right]</math>.


''' Finding the formula for the matrix <math>\ A</math>'''

Then, we can write the information from above in matrix notation
<math> 
A \left[ \begin{array}{cc} 4 & -3 \\ 3 & 4 \end{array} \right] = \left[ \begin{array}{cc} 4 & -3 \\ 3 & 4 \end{array} \right]\left[ \begin{array}{cc} 1 & 0  \\ 0 & -1 \end{array} \right].
</math>

We define the matrix <math>\ B</math>, where the columns of <math>\ B</math> are the eigenvectors and write the equation as

<math>AB = B\left[ \begin{array}{cc} 1 & 0  \\ 0 & -1 \end{array} \right].</math>

This leads us to
<math> A = B \left[ \begin{array}{cc}1 & 0  \\ 0 & -1\end{array} \right] B^{-1} </math>.


''' Calculating <math> \ A</math>'''

First the inverse of ''B'' is given by the usual method for 2x2 matrices (where <math> 25 = \det(B)</math>):

<math> B^{-1}  = \frac{1}{25} \left[ \begin{array}{cc}
4 & 3  \\ 
-3 & 4
\end{array} \right]  </math> 

We can now compute ''A'' as claimed:

<math> A = \left[ \begin{array}{cc}
4 & -3  \\ 
3 & 4
\end{array} \right] \left[ \begin{array}{cc}
1 & 0  \\ 
0 & -1
\end{array} \right] \left( \frac{1}{25}  \left[ \begin{array}{cc}
4 & 3  \\ 
-3 & 4
\end{array} \right]\right)  = \frac{1}{25} \left[ \begin{array}{cc}
7 & 24  \\ 
24 & -7
\end{array} \right] </math>.
statement_html:
Let \(T: \mathbb{R}^2 \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^2\) be the linear transformation that reflects points through the line 3x = 4y.

b) Using the result of a), find A (the standard matrix of T).
statement_latex:
Let $T: \mathbb{R}^2 \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^2$ be the linear
transformation that reflects points through the line \emph{3x = 4y}.

\textbf{b)} Using the result of
{a)},
find \emph{A} (the standard matrix of \emph{T}).
statement_raw:
Let <math> T: \mathbb{R}^2 \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^2 </math> be the linear transformation that reflects points through the line ''3x = 4y''.

'''b)''' Using the result of [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH221/April_2013/Question_07_(a)|a)]], find ''A'' (the standard matrix of ''T'').
